Posts.Content: Hi thanks so much for your advice, I had a good chat with my wonderful hubby last night and feel much better but decided to see my GP next week if i don't feel brighter by then. I had counselling after my radiotherapy as I had a mini meltdown as you say once treatments were over my brain suddenly kicked in and said "WHAT ON EARTH JUST HAPPENED" it helped at the time. I find that when i'm tired I get more emotional and I find it hard to admit when I need a rest.  I hate needing special treatment at work but I just can't keep up with shift work and I think others may think well it was two years ago I should be over it by now but it takes so much longer than I expected and that's frustrating for a get up and go girl. I hate having a whinge when so many others are suffering more than me and you are all so brave. love to you all and many thanks xxx

Posts.Content: HI please please go back and demand to be referred, its your body not theirs.I was 37 when I found a small lump at the top of my breast under my armpit in nov 2010 the gp thought it was a lymph node but referred me anyway and i;m glad she did as biopsy confirmed breast ca.  Whether yours is or not you deserve to be investigated so you can stop worrying or at least know you have been pro active. Good luck xxxx

Posts.Content: Thanks Yvonne your right i try to contain my emotions so i don't upset the family and work colleagues don't really want to know. People are polite and ask how you are but they don't really want the real answer.  I think i need to stop protecting everyone else and concentrate on myself. I can feel the love and support from you all and i'm so glad i signed up today. thank you xx

Posts.Content: Hi beevergirl, thanks for your dose of hope. I'm usually such a strong person and typically i think us women find it hard to admit when life gets too hard. its nice to be able to share with someone who understands xx
Posts.Title: staying positive

Posts.Content: HI all i'm new to this blogging so bare with me. I was diagnosed with breast ca 2 yrs ago had lumpectomy and radiotherapy,I'm 39 and pre menopausal so had 6 months of zoladex and 1yr of tamoxifen before the side effects became unbearable. I have been left with chronic fatigue, muscle and ligament weakness which led to constant pain and discomfort. I have two children and a busy working life which is stressful. I also lost my brother suddenly 6 months ago and everytime I feel slightly positive about the future I feel like I take one step forward and 3 steps back. I am finding it increasingly difficult to stay positive and cry most days. Is this normal 2 years in? will it get any better?
